subject: Re: tearDown() even if setUp() throws unexpected exception?
msgSnippet: ... test ... setUp ... TestSetup ... addons.sourceforge.net/junitx/extensions/TestSetup.html . thanks to all who replied.  i think that, rather than counting
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Vladimir R. Bossicard" <vladimir@b...>
wrote:
> > if Foo's ctor starts throwing exceptions, all of a sudden the
test
> > class is leaking connections, since tearDown() is not called if
setUp
> > () throws an unexpected exception.
>
> <ads>
> if you only want the tearDown method to be called, try the
TestSetup
> class of the JUnit-addons package
> <http://junit-
addons.sourceforge.net/junitx/extensions/TestSetup.html>.

thanks to all who replied. i think that, rather than counting on
myself to order my setUp() activities a certain, possibly-unobvious-
to-others way, i'll simply guard setUp() with a try/catch, and do
what's necessary to release the connection prior to setUp()
signalling the exception.

for those mroe intimate with the internals: would subclassing
TestCase and overriding runBare() to include setUp() in the try block
with runTest() constitute a breach of JUnit ethics/violation of the
spirit of the framework? seems like it might be a useful variation,
but i don't want to end up confusing folks. in essence, such a
subclass would be like junit-addons' TestSetup, but would be a
TestCase instead.

eager to read your thoughts.

cheers,
p
